EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to integrate training on eating disorders and treatment levels for health professionals. The Secretary will award grants for training on eating disorders, treatment levels, referral procedures, prevention strategies, and treatment methods. Entities seeking grants must submit an application outlining fund usage plans. Entities applying for a grant under this section must submit an application to the Secretary, including a plan for fund usage and training evaluation. Grant recipients are required to develop a training program focused on evidence-based practices for eating disorder identification, intervention, prevention, and treatment. Develop a training program with evidence-based practices for eating disorder identification, intervention, prevention, and treatment, including educational training and conferences. Topics may include prevention strategies, early intervention, and appropriate treatment methods for eating disorder patients. The training program should focus on identifying, intervening early, and treating eating disorder patients. It should also cover assessing health risk factors and developing treatment plans. The evaluation and reporting to the Secretary on these topics is essential. The training program should cover assessing health risk factors, developing treatment plans, and evaluating the effectiveness of the training in changing attitudes and behaviors of trainees. SEC. 7. EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR SCHOOL AND HIGHER EDUCATION PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of behaviors associated with eating disorders, as well as providing resources to individuals affected by eating disorders. The eligible entities receiving grants must conduct educational seminars on early identification, intervention, and prevention of eating disordered behaviors. They should also provide resources to individuals affected by eating disorders, in line with the BodyWise eating disorder initiative and relevant research. Eligible entities include states, territories, tribes, and organizations. The term "eligible entity" in this section refers to states, territories, tribes, organizations, and educational institutions eligible to receive grants for conducting educational seminars on eating disorders. SEC. 8. PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health will conduct public service announcements to educate the public on various aspects of eating disorders, including types, seriousness, identification, intervention, prevention, discrimination, bullying, and the impact of media on self-esteem and body image. The Director of the National Institute of Mental Health collaborates with centers of excellence and community-based national nonprofit resources to prevent eating disorders, address body image issues, and educate the public on the effects of media on self-esteem. SEC. 9. CLARIFYING APPLICATION OF EXISTING PARITY LAW. Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include the treatment of permanent exclusions under mental health and substance use disorder benefits in group health plans or health insurance coverage. Violation of this amendment would occur if these benefits are not provided as required. The amendment to Section 2726 of the Public Health Service Act prohibits group or individual health insurance plans from permanently excluding mental health or substance use disorder benefits for a specific condition.
